description.plain:
Todd Anthony Shaw, better known as Too $hort, is a rapper, producer and actor from Oakland, California. He and his family moved up to Oakland from Los Angeles in the early 1980s, and he established himself as an artist selling “special request” custom tapes, leading into his first official album Don’t Stop Rappin' on the independent 75 Girls label.

He got a major label deal with Jive Records, first releasing his 1987 album Born To Mack before going on to release a number of albums and popular singles such as “Gettin' It,” “Shake That Monkey,” “Blow the Whistle,” “The Ghetto,” and “I’m a Player” among others. After five decades in the rap game, Too $hort joined his first group, the supergroup MOUNT WESTMORE with E-40, Ice Cube and Snoop Dogg, and they released their debut album Bad MF’s in 2022.

songs.full_title: Blow the Whistle by Too $hort
songs.title: Blow the Whistle

description.plain:
“Blow The Whistle” is  the first single from Too $hort’s 16th album, Blow the Whistle.

As explained by Too $hort himself:

It’s a sports metaphor. I’m just saying ‘blow the whistle’ on the people who can’t fucking hang. “You’re doing too much, you’re in the penalty box,” for people who aren’t doing it right. I was just playing on the sports metaphor and talking a little shit and doing the Too $hort spin on the subject.

songs.full_title: I'm a Player by Too $hort
songs.title: I’m a Player

description.plain:
Main single off “Get in Where You Fit In”, and one of Too Short’s more well known songs (as well as his first G-Funk single); an ode to pimping and playing, or having sex with multiple women without deep feelings. Of course, Big Pun didn’t exactly agree with Too Short.

The primary sample and hook is from Bootsy Collins' “Hollywood Squares”.

songs.full_title: The Ghetto by Too $hort
songs.title: The Ghetto

description.plain: “The Ghetto” is a 1990 single by Oakland rapper Too Short from his album Short Dog’s in the House. The song was featured on the fictional radio station Radio Los Santos in the videogame Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas. The instrumental was based on the Donny Hathaway song of the same name. The song discusses the struggles of living in the ghetto and the difficulty of getting out of the ghetto to live a more successful life. It also discusses issues such as drug abuse and racial pride. Too Short is mostly known for his raps relating to sex and women, however he did have some songs with a deeper message and serious economic and social commentary. “The Ghetto” being an example of this.

songs.full_title: Freaky Tales by Too $hort
songs.title: Freaky Tales

description.plain:
“Freaky Tales” is often considered Too Short’s real breakout hit, released in 1987, in his first full major album release.

Freaky Tales is perhaps one of the most important songs in West Coast hip hop. The instrumental showed how the West Coast was beginning to develop a more distinct sound away from the East Coast. It was also the first “dirty” rap song to be released and gain mainstream attention in the United States, during a time when cussing even in rap was a no-no. It also marked the beginning of Too Short’s dirty rap image as well.

Incidentally, Too Short had said that the song was originally meant to be a parody of the pimping industry itself, and none of it was meant to be taken seriously.

songs.full_title: Cusswords by Too $hort
songs.title: Cusswords

description.plain:
What appears to be just another typical Too Short rap has more going on than it seems. The song was actually made as a response to critics who thought Too Short’s more sloppy delivery wouldn’t last long. The song also appears to be a vent against the U.S. government as well, such as referencing the events of the Iran-Contra affair.

Also, this song introduced the world outside California to the term “frisco dyke”, 3 years before Fuck Wit Dre Day did.

songs.full_title: So You Want to Be a Gangster by Too $hort
songs.title: So You Want to Be a Gangster
songs.title_with_featured: So You Want to Be a Gangster

description.plain:
In this gem off Too Short’s 1992 album Shorty the Pimp, “So You Want to Be a Gangster” tells about the darkside of the gang life, as well as a “bad things lead to worse things” kind of story as well. Compared to many other Too Short songs, “So You Want to Be a Gangster” has a very dark and serious tone, and is a good example of some of the more social commentary songs Too Short released in the early 90s.

The song is featured in Grand Theft Auto V on the radio station West Coast Classics.

songs.title_with_featured: Ain’t My Girlfriend (Ft. French Montana, Jeremih, Joyner Lucas & Ty Dolla $ign)

description.plain:
Originally released as a single in 2016, Too $hort recruits Ty Dolla $ign, French Montana, Jeremih and Joyner Lucas for “Ain’t My Girlfriend”, off his 2018 release, The Pimp Tape.
The original version did not have Joyner Lucas on the track, and Jeremih’s verse was a little longer. The video for the song was released nearly two years later, with a new verse from Joyner, and a shorter verse from Jeremih.
